Will you talk to Mr. James Sadler? He said that he hasn't completed his
sign up with us because the payment for the damages of their car is not yet

episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the James Sadler motor vehicle accident, dated 4/07/2023, with client James Sadler. On May 23, 2023, at 11:44:42 AM (-0400), Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm sent an email from jessa@whaleylawfirm.com to Aaron Whaley at agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com regarding Mr. Sadler. The message, addressed to “Hi Atty. Whaley,” asks Aaron to speak with Mr. Sadler.

Jessa explains that Sadler has not completed his signup with the firm because payment for the damages to his car has not yet been made. She adds that obtaining legal representation should not affect his claim for property damage. She also notes that PIP is asking her to issue a letter instructing not to use the Letter of Representation (LOR) she recently sent, since the client is not fully signed up yet. The email closes with the sign-off, “All the best,” followed by Jessa Galosmo’s contact details for the Whaley Law Firm: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.
episodes.author: Jessa

This narrative summarizes email communications for the motor vehicle accident case of James Sadler (Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023), regarding claim number 17-47X4-43M.

On July 17, 2023, at 4:39 PM Eastern, Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm sent an email to State Farm Auto Medical Claims regarding the client. In the message, she stated that the client is still waiting to see whether he needs to go back on treatment, with a decision expected by July 19. She noted that the client’s last treatment with Pro Rehab occurred on July 5.

Earlier that same day, Auto Medical Claims at State Farm replied with a standard message directing the recipient to open the attached documents for more claim information or next steps. The reply also included privacy and security guidance, advising not to include sensitive personal information (such as Social Security numbers, financial account numbers, driver’s license numbers, or health information) in emails, and suggesting the use of a secure email channel by contacting the claim associate if such information must be transmitted.

The reply further included boilerplate promotional text about receiving claim contact cards via text, encouraging the recipient to text AUTO to 62789 for an Auto claim card or to text HOME to 62789 for a Homeowners claim card. The message concluded with the usual signatures and boilerplate.

Signature details from Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm follow, including her phone number (502) 357-9975 and fax number (502) 364-9363.

Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023
Client: James Sadler

__Re: What is the status of my claim ? The techs at Pro Rehab assured me there was one contact to get case history from. I was there for 7 sessions for an hour or more and exercises daily in between for 3-4 weeks.__
From: Jessa Galosmo [jessa@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:jessa@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [jmsadler1@hotmail.com](mailto:jmsadler1@hotmail.com) James Sadler
Date: Wed, 23 Aug 2023 11:17:03 -0400

Hi James,

We are still waiting for the records and bills from Pro Rehab. I did a
follow up again with them today and resend the request. I was assured they
already received the request and submitted it to the records department. I
tried to call the records dept. but I am only getting voicemail. Regarding
the deductible, yes it will be included in the final settlement.

On Wed, Aug 23, 2023 at 10:59?AM James Sadler wrote:

> State Farm told my significant and me that although their insured was at
> fault, they had to apply our $500 deductible. State Farm said that $500
> would be included in any final settlement.
> The driver who ran that red light totaled 3 vehicles in 30 seconds and I
> have spent countless hours in pain and rehab due to his negligence. Please
> get me up to date on this April matter. Your client, James M Sadler
>
> Sent from my iPad

-- 
All the best,
Jessa Galosmo
Whaley Law Firm
Ph: (502)357-9975
Fax: (502)364-9363
episodes.natural_language:
This case note concerns James Sadler’s motor vehicle accident claim (Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023) for client James Sadler. In his inquiry about the status of the claim, he notes that the technicians at Pro Rehab had assured him there was one contact to obtain his case history. He attended seven sessions, each lasting an hour or more, and he performed daily exercises in between for three to four weeks.

On August 23, 2023, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm emailed James Sadler at 11:17:03 AM to provide an update. She wrote that they are still waiting for the records and bills from Pro Rehab, and that she had followed up again and resent the request. She was assured that Pro Rehab had already received the request and had submitted it to the records department. She also said she attempted to call the records department but was directed to voicemail. Regarding the deductible, she confirmed that it will be included in the final settlement.

Earlier that same day, in a message sent around 10:59 AM, James Sadler wrote that State Farm told his significant other and him that although State Farm’s insured was at fault, they had to apply their $500 deductible, and that the $500 would be included in any final settlement. He described the driver who ran the red light as having totaled three vehicles in 30 seconds and stated that he had spent countless hours in pain and rehab due to the negligence. He requested an up-to-date update on this April matter. The message was signed with “Sent from my iPad.” The note concludes with Jessa Galosmo’s closing: All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm, Ph: (502)357-9975, Fax: (502)364-9363.
episodes.author: Jessa

Client chipped tooth while eating. Went to the same dentist and had it repaired. DOS: 10/23/23 and cost was $498.00. Need to make sure this is not included with demand to SF. 

 

On upcoming Monday, they are set to extract tooth cracked in accident. Client says the plan is to leave that tooth open for another couple of months. episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on October 25, 2023, from Bryce Koon of Whaley Law Firm to James Sadler regarding his motor vehicle accident (case James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023).

The client reports that he chipped a tooth while eating and went to the same dentist to have it repaired. The date of service for the repair was October 23, 2023, and the cost was $498.00. He asked to make sure this amount is not included with the demand to SF.

Regarding future dental work, the client states that on the upcoming Monday the tooth cracked in the accident is to be extracted. The plan is to leave that tooth open for another couple of months. The client will be in Gulf Shores, Alabama from January through March and may not be able to obtain subsequent treatment until his return. He will call with an update following the extraction on Monday.

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023
Client: James Sadler

__Text Message__
__Message:__ Got the post for my replacement tooth from the 4-7-23 accident. Have paid Dr Mills about 3600 to date with insurance paying about 1150 of that. Final on new tooth about 2-3 months away with Drs Mills and Wilson. This process as a result of phone meeting with Mr Whaley I had last Fall about pain and suffering I had before we discovered the cracked tooth that was pulled. Please acknowledge this text and advise what info you need from me. Thank you. James Sadler
__Date and Time:__ 2024-03-13 
__From Number:__ +15024175186 
__To Number:__ +15023655043
__Direction:__ Inbound
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on March 13, 2024, with James Sadler regarding the motor vehicle accident that occurred on 4-7-2023 and the dental treatment related to a replacement tooth. In an inbound text, Mr. Sadler states that he has received the post for his replacement tooth from the 4-7-23 accident. He reports that he has paid Dr. Mills approximately $3,600 to date, with insurance paying about $1,150 of that amount. He estimates that the final placement of the new tooth will be about two to three months away, with Drs. Mills and Wilson handling the work. He explains that this process is the result of a phone meeting with Mr. Whaley last Fall about pain and suffering he experienced before the cracked tooth was discovered and pulled. He asks that the text be acknowledged and requests guidance on what information is needed from him. The message is signed, James Sadler.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023
Client: James Sadler

I returned Mr Sadler's call - he is currently in the process of having a tooth implanted - the "post" was inserted about 2 weeks ago and it will take approximately another 6 to 8 weeks of healing before the tooth will be attached to post. He said following his MVA he was experiencing a lot of pain - but did not realize his tooth had suffered a crack due to the accident. His employer's insurance covered some of the cost of implant - but he has spent approximately $2,000+ out of pocket so far. He will continue to update us. He was not entirely sure of the dental facility name - but said he will get that info for us. #cc
episodes.natural_language:
I returned Mr. Sadler's call regarding his ongoing dental treatment following a motor vehicle accident. He is currently in the process of having a tooth implanted; the post was inserted about two weeks ago, and it will take approximately another six to eight weeks of healing before the tooth can be attached to the post. He reported that after the MVA he experienced a lot of pain, but did not realize his tooth had cracked as a result of the accident.

His employer's insurance has covered some of the implant costs, but he has spent approximately $2,000+ out of pocket so far. He will continue to update us. He was not entirely sure of the dental facility name, but said he will obtain that information for us. #cc

On August 14, 2024, an inbound text message was received in the James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023 matter from +15024175186 to +15023655043. The message provided a summary of out-of-pocket expenses supported by receipts: dental bills from dentists Wilson ($2,055), Mills ($1,740), and Cook ($279); plus Pro Rehab charges of 30 sessions at $7 each, totaling $210. Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023 concerns client James Sadler.

In a message that began the chain, dated September 11, 2024, at 3:07 PM, Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm wrote to Front Desk at stmatthewsdentistry.com. She stated: “Hello, Please see the attached request for medical records of James Sadler. We specifically need his prior records dating back at least 10 years. Thank you for your assistance in this matter.” Her signature followed, identifying her as Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm, with contact details Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.

Later that same day, September 11, 2024, at 4:10? PM, Front Desk replied with a long list of attachments. The correspondence also included a closing signature block from Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm, with her contact details (Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363). The Front Desk signaled that these were attached as part of the response.

Separately, on September 12, 2024 at 11:01 AM, Jessa Galosmo forwarded the entire thread, including the above exchanges, to Greg Whaley.

In the forwarded content, the thread shows the initial request for medical records (dated September 11, 2024) and the subsequent communication indicating the need for a different format for treatment notes (due to an inability to open a PRNX file) as well as the PDF attachment noted by the Front Desk on September 12, 2024.

The emails also included the Whaley Law Firm signature for Jessa Galosmo, with the same phone and fax numbers, and the Aiken Family Dentistry signature block with the practice’s address and contact details, reinforcing the exchange between Whaley Law Firm and the dental provider.

Overall, the record shows a coordinated effort in September 2024 to obtain James Sadler’s dental and medical records dating back at least ten years, including a request for older treatment notes in an accessible format, a substantial set of attached dental records and images from Aiken Family Dentistry, and a subsequent forwarding of the full correspondence to a member of the Whaley firm.

On January 7, 2025 at 1:59 PM, Bryce Koon wrote to Aaron Whaley with James Sadler MVA 4/07/2023 in the cc line, starting with, “This is actually one on my list to talk to you about.” He outlined the current settlement posture: the insurer’s top offer is $7,688, and it is unclear how or why they are stuck at this number. They had previously offered $5,500 without dental records and bills, and their offer rose to $7,688 once those records and bills were provided. Bryce countered at $35,000, but the insurer stated they would stay at $7,688. A settlement statement has been prepared based on this $7,688 figure, but they have not yet obtained the potential Delta Dental lien for the dentist’s payments. Bryce stated that he believes the claim is worth more than the current offer, though he is not sure how much more, especially with the dental component. He asked for Aaron’s thoughts before speaking with the client and requested guidance on which direction to steer the client—litigation or settlement.

Earlier, on the same day, Aaron Whaley replied at 2:59 PM (time shown as 2:59?PM in the thread): “Please call.”

The email also contains a forwarded RingCentral message, dated Tuesday, January 7, 2025 at 1:59 PM, with the subject: “New Voice Message from JAMES SADLER (502) 417-5186 on 01/07/2025.” The message was addressed to Aaron Whaley. The message details are as follows: a new voice message from James Sadler (phone number 502-417-5186) received on Tuesday, January 07, 2025 at 1:59 PM, with a length of 00:28, intended for the number 502-583-4022 (Aaron Whaley). The voicemail preview reads: “Hey, Mr. Whaley, this is James Sadler. I am in Louisville and I had a wreck almost 22 months ago and I think you are working on a case for me, but I have not heard anything from Nobody answers my call, so thought to touch base with you and see, what do you think I should do 502-417-5186.” The message further instructs to listen to this message over the phone or log in to the RingCentral account with the main number, extension number, and password, and notes that voicemails can also be managed in the RingCentral account.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

__Text Message__
__Message:__ I began having serious pain within a few days of the accident that occurred 4-7-23. I made multiple trips to 3 dentists and Baptist East Hospital for x-rays. I went to rehab for my jaw 9 times over 4 weeks. The last endo specialist found the shattered tooth when he took x-rays before a root canal.
I continued to work 5-10 hour shifts at Churchill Downs in severe pain to keep my health and dental benefits which paid much of the treatment resulting from the accident. I had to work without pain medication since I handle tens of thousands of dollars each shift during the months of May, June, September and November these past 21 months.
After the shattered tooth was pulled, I had to do without my lower jaw tooth while the pocket healed for the new tooth. This period was also very painful. I finally got the new tooth over a year after the accident.
I saw the guilty party about to run the red light about 50 yards out. I gritted my teeth and feared the worst. Another car was struck and the gui

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on January 14, 2025 with James Sadler regarding a motor vehicle accident that occurred on April 7, 2023. In a text message, dated January 14, 2025, Mr. Sadler stated that he began having serious pain within a few days of the accident and that he made multiple trips to three dentists and Baptist East Hospital for X-rays. He also noted that he went to rehab for his jaw nine times over four weeks, and that the last endodontist found a shattered tooth when taking X-rays before a root canal.

He described continuing to work 5–10 hour shifts at Churchill Downs in severe pain to preserve his health and dental benefits, which paid much of the treatment resulting from the accident. He added that he had to work without pain medication since he handles tens of thousands of dollars each shift, during the months of May, June, September, and November these past 21 months. After the shattered tooth was pulled, he had to do without his lower jaw tooth while the pocket healed for the new tooth; this period was also very painful. He finally got the new tooth over a year after the accident.

He also recounted seeing the guilty party about to run the red light about 50 yards away, gritting his teeth and fearing the worst. Another car was struck, and the note ends with that event as described. The inbound text was sent on 2025-01-14 from +1-502-417-5186 to +1-502-365-5043.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Sadler v. Tafesse, the case James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023 lists James Sadler as the client. The correspondence shown is an email chain between counsel regarding discovery requests, with the subject line Re: Sadler v. Tafesse. The June 3, 2025 communication came from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, to Allison L. Rief, Attorney at Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC, with Jennifer Styles and the James Sadler MVA 4/07/2023 Filevine project address copied on the message. The June 3, 2025 email, dated 11:44:39 a.m. Eastern Time, includes the Whaley Law Firm’s physical address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact numbers: phone 502-365-5043 and fax 502-237-3207. It also repeats the standard confidentiality disclaimer stating the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information, with instructions to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error and a warning not to disclose or forward the information.

The June 3 message followed an April 11, 2025 exchange in which Allison L. Rief, an attorney with Dilbeck and Myers, indicated she had met with Mr. Tafesse that morning to answer discovery requests and requested that the sending party provide a Word document copy of their requests so she could draft them. Bryce Koon replied later that day, at about 12:16 p.m., stating, “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached. Thank you,” and signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information. The email was sent to Allison Rief and cc’d to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Jennifer Styles (jennifer@dilbeckandmyers.com), and the James Sadler MVA 4/07/2023 Filevine project address JamesSadlerMVAZ3759369@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 12:14 p.m., Allison Rief had written to Bryce Koon asking if they could provide a Word document copy of the requests so she could draft responses. Bryce’s 12:16 p.m. reply indicated that attachments would be sent, and he again included the same parties in the CC field. Allison’s response around 12:18 p.m. that day was, “Appreciated – thank you,” followed by her professional signature with the Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC contact details and a confidentiality notice similar to the one included in the later messages. Allison’s signature lists the Dilbeck and Myers address as 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222, with telephone 502.595.6500 and fax 502.595.6504.

In summary, the record shows ongoing discovery communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck and Myers related to the Sadler v. Tafesse case, including requests for Word-document copies of discovery requests, a meeting with Mr. Tafesse to discuss those requests, and subsequent collaborative follow-up emails on April 11, 2025, culminating in Bryce Koon’s follow-up on June 3, 2025, requesting status on the outstanding requests. The correspondence consistently includes the case reference, relevant participants, and standard confidentiality disclosures typical of attorney communications.

episodes.natural_language:
This case note pertains to James Sadler in the matter captioned Sadler v. Tafesse (an April 7, 2023 motor vehicle accident), with the client identified as James Sadler. The document lines up a sequence of written discovery activities and deposition scheduling communications between counsel, culminating in a request for deposition dates for Mr. Tafesse and an invitation to revisit informal negotiations before further depositions.

On June 20, 2025, at 11:25:48 AM Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Allison Rief, attorney for the defense at Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC. He noted that written discovery appeared to be complete and asked for potential dates for Mr. Tafesse’s deposition at the earliest convenience. He also indicated that Mr. Sadler is widely available over the next two months if the defense wished to coordinate his deposition as well. Koon asked to be advised whether the parties would like to revisit informal negotiations before committing additional time and resources to depositions. He provided his firm’s contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone 502-365-5043; Fax 502-237-3207.

Earlier communications in the chain reflect ongoing discovery-related activity. On June 16, 2025, at 4:28 PM (noted as “4:28?PM” in the record), Allison L. Rief, attorney for Dilbeck and Myers, reported that a storm on Friday had delayed Mr. Tafesse, but he was able to come by the office that day to verify his discovery responses, which were attached to the message. Rief’s notice included firm contact details: Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC, 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone 502-595-6500; Fax 502-595-6504. The message also included standard confidentiality language.

On June 13, 2025, at 11:04 AM, Allison Rief had previously indicated that Mr. Tafesse would be coming in that afternoon to verify discovery, with the expectation that she would be able to forward the verified discovery soon afterwards. Her contact details and the firm’s information were included in that email as well.

On June 11, 2025, at 11:29 AM, Bryce Koon asked Allison Rief to advise when the parties might expect responses to outstanding discovery requests.

On June 3, 2025, at 11:44 AM, Bryce Koon followed up again, requesting an update on the discovery requests.

Earlier in the year, on April 11, 2025, there was a sequence concerning the drafting of discovery requests. Allison Rief wrote at 12:14 PM to indicate she had met with Mr. Tafesse that morning to answer discovery requests and requested that the opposing side send a Word document copy of their requests so she could draft responses. Bryce Koon replied at 12:16 PM, stating, “Good afternoon counsel, please see attached.” The message also noted that it had been cc’d to relevant recipients and included the dedicated Filevine project address for the Sadler MVA file. At 12:18 PM, Allison Rief replied, “Appreciated – thank you.”

Also on April 11, 2025, Bryce Koon sent a message at 12:16 PM stating, “Please see attached,” in reference to the discovery requests. This was followed by Allison’s 12:18 PM reply expressing appreciation.

In sum, the record reflects a coordinated effort across multiple weeks to complete discovery, verify discovery responses (including handling weather-related delays), and schedule depositions, with a current emphasis on identifying deposition dates for Mr. Tafesse and coordinating Mr. Sadler’s deposition within the next two months, while remaining open to informal settlement discussions before expending additional resources on depositions. The communications identify two law firms (The Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC), their respective representatives (Bryce Koon and Allison Rief), as well as the involved parties and project contact points (including the James Sadler MVA Filevine project address).

Case: James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023. The client is James Sadler.

Between April and July 2025, counsel communications unfolded in the James Sadler v. Tafesse matter. The Whaley Law Firm’s W. Bryce Koon, Esq., wrote to Allison L. Rief, Attorney at Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC, with copies to Brooke Gallagher and the James Sadler MVA Filevine project email address (JamesSadlerMVAZ3759369@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The initial excerpt in the record shows a July 23, 2025 message in which Koon followed up with counsel, requesting any update on the matter and signing off with his firm’s contact information and a standard confidentiality notice.

Earlier in the chain, on June 20, 2025, Allison Rief responded to a request to coordinate Mr. Sadler’s deposition, indicating she would confer with Mr. Tafesse and review calendars to find a workable time and would get back to the sender. In the same exchange, Bryce Koon replied (in a message dated June 20, 2025 at 11:26 AM) noting that, with written discovery apparently complete, they should provide potential deposition dates for Mr. Tafesse as soon as possible. He added that Mr. Sadler was widely available over the next two months if their calendars could accommodate coordinating his deposition as well, and he asked whether the parties would like to revisit informal negotiations before investing more time and resources in depositions. The message was sent from The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone number as 502-365-5043 and fax as 502-237-3207, and it included the standard confidentiality notice.

On June 16, 2025, Allison Rief wrote that Mr. Tafesse was delayed by a Friday storm but had been by the office that day to verify his discovery responses; she attached the verification (discovery responses). Her signature block identified Dilbeck and Myers, PLLC, at 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222, with a telephone number of 502.595.6500 and fax 502.595.6504, and she included the customary confidentiality notice.

Earlier still, on June 13, 2025, Allison Rief had told Bryce that Tafesse would come in that afternoon to verify his discovery, and she expected to be able to send the verified discovery shortly thereafter. This message also carried the Dilbeck and Myers contact details and confidentiality notice.

A prior thread shows Bryce Koon’s June 11, 2025 email to Allison Rief (and others, with the James Sadler MVA Filevine address copied) asking when the parties might expect responses to their outstanding discovery requests. The June 11 message was followed by a June 3, 2025 note from Bryce asking counsel to advise when they may expect responses to the outstanding discovery requests, again with the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and confidentiality notices.

There is an earlier exchange dated April 11, 2025 in the chain, in which Allison Rief replied with “ Appreciated – thank you” and Bryce Koon had sent a message to Allison earlier that day (12:16 PM) with copies to the Whaley firm and others; the details of that April 11 thread are partially captured in the record, confirming ongoing discovery-related communications before the June routine.

In sum, the record shows a coordinated effort from April through June 2025 to obtain and verify discovery materials, schedule and conduct depositions, and align the calendar for Mr. Tafesse’s deposition while also coordinating Mr. Sadler’s availability for deposition over the ensuing two-month window. The communications repeatedly reference written discovery as the trigger for moving toward depositions, the storm-related delay in Tafesse’s appearance, and the plan to revisit any informal negotiations if desired before expending further resources on depositions. The communications repeatedly carry the parties’ standard confidentiality notices and reference the same filevine project address for James Sadler’s MVA matter, along with the Whaley Law Firm’s and Dilbeck & Myers’ contact information.

For the James Sadler case (ID James-Sadler-MVA-4-07-2023) involving client James Sadler, I completed comprehensive case file organization using an eight-bucket system. I organized 85 files into the following categories: Client, Investigation, Medical Records, Insurance, Lien, Negotiation Settlement, and Litigation.

I deleted 6 duplicate files and applied a standardized naming convention: YYYY-MM-DD - Client - Category - Originator - Description. I created provider-specific subdirectories within Medical Records and also deleted 16 orphaned .md files that had no companion PDFs. The case folder is now 100% organized with all files properly categorized and named.

Remaining files in the root directory are: contacts.json (system file), james-sadler-tx-notes.prnx (treatment notes), and three .docx files requiring manual review.
